titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Brooks McNamara Papers MSS.162
titlestmt.author: Daniel Hoffheins in 2007 and Dasha Chapman in 2007-2008, with further editing by Jennifer E. Neal in 2018

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-20 17:15:37 -0400.

change.item: Updated by Jennifer E. Neal to include materials integrated from accession number 2009.162, and for compliance with DACS and ACM Required Elements for Archival Description

did.unittitle: Brooks McNamara Papers

physdesc.extent: in 30 boxes, 5 record cartons, 2 manuscript boxes, and 1 oversize flat box

did.abstract: The Brooks McNamara Papers are comprised almost entirely of McNamara's subject files on the expansive breadth of theater, drama, and performance in early American, early British, and contemporary American life. Materials include articles, brochures, catalogues, correspondence, drafts, magazines, manuscripts, newsletters, newspaper clippings, pamphlets, photocopies, photographs, postcards, posters, programs, student projects slides, audiocassettes, 8mm film, reel to reel video, reel to reel audio, and DVD-Rs.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The collection was transferred from the Free Library of Philadelphia and donated by Brooks McNamara in 2005; additional materials were donated in 2009. The accession numbers associated with this collection are 2005.162 and 2009.162.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materias are arranged in six series:

list.item: Series V: Plays, written with Laurence Senelick
Series VI: Course Materials and Student Papers

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Brooks McNamara began teaching at NYU's Graduate Drama Department in 1968, and was instrumental in its transformation into the Performance Studies Department, which officially was started in 1980. He founded the Shubert Archives in 1976 and served as its Director for 20 years. McNamara's research, writing, and curatorial pursuits resulted in numerous publications, exhibitions, productions, and archival collections. His life work spanned the fields of theatre history, popular entertainments, public celebrations, and New York performance history. After retiring in 1996, McNamara remained Professor Emeritus of Performance Studies and Director Emeritus of the Shubert Archive. He died in May 2009.
The New York Concert Saloon: the Devil's Own Nights. Cambridge, U.K.; New York: Cambridge University Press, 2002.
Gower Champion Dance and American Musical Theatre. With David Payne-Carter and Stephen Nelson. Westport, Conn.: Greenwood Press, 1999.

Day of Jubilee : The Great Age Of Public Celebrations In New York, 1788-1909 : Illustrated From The Collections Of The Museum Of The City Of New York. New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press, 1997.
Inside the Minstrel Mask : Readings In Nineteenth-Century Blackface Minstrelsy. Edited with Annemarie Bean and James V. Hatch. Hanover, NH: Wesleyan University Press, 1996.
The Merry Muldoons and the Brighteyes Affair. New York: Orchard Books, 1992.
The Shuberts of Broadway: A History Drawn From The Collections Of The Shubert Archive. With the Shubert Archive. New York: Oxford University Press, 1990.

Edwin Booth's Legacy: Treasures From The Hampden-Booth Theatre Collection At The Players. Selected and organized by Raymond Wemmlinger and Brooks McNamara; catalogue by Raymond Wemmlinger and Brooks McNamara; with contributions by Robert A. Carter, José Ferrer and Paul Myers. [New York]: Hampden-Booth Theatre Library, 1989.
Plays from The Contemporary American Theater. New York: New American Library, 1988.
The Drama Review: Thirty Years of Commentary on The Avant-Garde. Edited by Brooks McNamara and Jill Dolan. Ann Arbor, Mich.: UMI Research Press, c1986.
American Popular Entertainments: Jokes, Monologues, Bits, and Sketches. [1st Ed.] New York City: Performing Arts Journal Publications, 1983.
Step right up. [1st ed.] Garden City, N.Y., Doubleday, 1976.
Theatres, Spaces, Environments: Eighteen Projects. Co-authored with Jerry Rojo and Richard Schechner. New York: Drama Book Specialists, 1975.
The American Playhouse in the Eighteenth Century. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1969.

"'For laughing purposes only': the literature of American popular entertainment." The American Stage: Social and Economic Issues from the Colonial Period to the Present. [Eds.] Ron Engle and Tice L. Miller. Cambridge [England]; New York: Cambridge University Press, 1993.

"'Something glorius': Greenwich Village and the theater." Greenwich Village: Culture and Counterculture. [Eds.] Rick Beard and Leslie Berlowitz, with the Museum of the City of New York. New Brunswick, N.J.: Published for the Museum of the City of New York by Rutgers University Press, 1993.
"The entertainment district at the end of the 1930s." Inventing Times Square: Commerce And Culture at the Crossroads of the World. William Robert Taylor. New York: Russell Sage Foundation, 1991.
"Broadway: A Theatre Historian's Perspective." TDR, Vol. 45, No. 4 (Winter, 2001), pp. 125-128.
"Michael Kirby: 1931-1997." Richard Schechner; Brooks McNamara. TDR, Vol. 41, No. 3 (Autumn, 1997), pp. 5-8.
"Talking." The Drama Review: TDR, Vol. 31, No. 2 (Summer, 1987), pp. 39-56.
"Processional Performance: An Introduction." Barbara Kirshenblatt-Gimblett; Brooks McNamara. The Drama Review: TDR, Vol. 29, No. 3, Processional Performance (Autumn, 1985), pp. 2-5.
"The Medicine Show Log: Reconstructing a Traditional American Entertainment." The Drama Review: TDR, Vol. 28, No. 3, Reconstruction (Autumn, 1984), pp. 74-97.
"TDR: Memoirs of the Mouthpiece, 1955-1983." The Drama Review: TDR, Vol. 27, No. 4, Anniversary Issue: Dreams, Proposals, Manifestos (Winter, 1983), pp. 3-21.
"Stuart Sherman's Third Spectacle." The Drama Review: TDR, Vol. 20, No. 2, American Theatre Issue (Jun., 1976), pp. 47-55.
"An Interview with Percy Press and a Portfolio of Buskers." Percy Press; Brooks McNamara. Educational Theatre Journal, Vol. 27, No. 3, Popular Theatre (Oct., 1975), pp. 313-322.
"'A Congress of Wonders,' the Rise and Fall of the Dime Museum.' Emerson Society Quarterly, 20:3 (1974), 201-261.
"Popular Entertainments Issue: An Introduction." The Drama Review: TDR, Vol. 18, No. 1, Popular Entertainments (Mar., 1974), pp. 3-4.
"Scenography of Popular Entertainment." The Drama Review: TDR, Vol. 18, No. 1, Popular Entertainments (Mar., 1974), pp. 16-24.
"Spartakiade." John E. Bonn; Nathaniel Buchwald; Brooks McNamara; Mady Schuman. The Drama Review: TDR, Vol. 17, No. 4, International Festival Issue (Dec., 1973), pp. 99-112.
"Vessel: The Scenography of Meredith Monk. An Interview." Brooks McNamara; Meredith Monk. The Drama Review: TDR, Vol. 16, No. 1 (Mar., 1972), pp. 87-103.
"The Indian Medicine Show." Educational Theatre Journal, Vol. 23, No. 4 (Dec., 1971), pp. 431-445.

"Paterson Strike Pageant." Brooks McNamara; Jessie Ashley; F. Sumner Boyd; Mabel Dodge; William D. Haywood; John Reed; Margaret H. Sanger. The Drama Review: TDR, Vol. 15, No. 3 (Summer, 1971), pp. 60-71.
"Scene Design: 1876-1965 Ibsen, Chekhov, Strindberg." The Drama Review: TDR, Vol. 13, No. 2, Naturalism Revisited (Winter, 1968), pp. 77-91.
"Group III: Developing and Improving Artistic Leadership." Educational Theatre Journal, Vol. 20, No. 2, International Conference on Theatre Education and Development (Aug., 1968), pp. 291-297.
"David Douglass and the Beginnings of American Theater Architecture." Winterthur Portfolio, Vol. 3 (1967), pp. 112-135.
"The Stratford Jubilee: Dram to Garrick's Vanity." Educational Theatre Journal, Vol. 14, No. 2 (May, 1962), pp. 135-140.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact fales.library@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact fales.library@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Brooks McNamara Papers; MSS 162; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The 2009 accretion was added to the end of Series I: Subject Files. Slides were rehoused in archival slide preservers and new acid-free folders; original order and original folder titles were maintained. One audio reel and two film reels were re-housed in appropriate containers.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Mark Hall Amitin/ World of Culture for the Performing Arts, Inc. Archive (MSS.121)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Brooks McNamara Papers reflect McNamara's life work as a scholar and professor at NYU. The collection is comprised almost entirely of McNamara's subject files on the expansive breadth of theater, drama, and performance in early American, early British, and contemporary American life.

Organized in one main series of McNamara's subject files, as well as five smaller series which document his scholarly and creative writing, the collection features prominent sections of resources on Broadway, Circuses, Environmental Performance, Fairs and Festivals, Medicine Shows, Minstrelsy, Street Entertainments, Theatre and Theatres, and Vaudeville, as well as McNamara's own work as a scholar. One is able to trace the early development of Performance Studies as a discipline through McNamara's framing of "Popular Entertainments": performance and theatre on the stage, in the street, and in everyday life.

Collection materials consist of articles, brochures, catalogues, correspondence, drafts, magazines, manuscripts, newsletters, newspaper clippings, pamphlets, photocopies, photographs, postcards, posters, programs, student projects slides, audiocassettes, 8mm film, reel to reel video, reel to reel audio, and DVD-Rs.

The general date range for the collection spans the early-1970s to the mid-1990s, as this is when McNamara was actively collecting these materials. However, there are also historical pamphlets and booklets dating from the turn of the century through the 1960s.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Brooks McNamara, was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

did.unittitle: Series I: Subject Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I contains contents articles, news clippings, programs, brochures, fliers, correspondence, photographs, postcards, student work, course materials, slides, audiocassettes, 8mm film, reel to reel video, reel to reel audio, and DVD-Rs from his time as a professor in NYU's Performance Studies Department. McNamara used his own subject headings to organize his scholarly research on popular entertainments, and they indicate his framing of performance both historically and in its prominent role in everyday life.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized alphabetically according to McNamara's own subject headings. All folder titles that were not in McNamara's original index are marked in brackets. Most often the folders are listed as undated because the materials were either collected from a wide range of years, or they do not have dates on them at all. Due to the large number of items in each folder, contents are not listed in detail, but rather by material type. In rare cases, an item of note is described. Materials in the 2009 accretion, boxes 36-38, were added to the end of Series I; original order and folder titles were retained.

did.unittitle: Index to P.E. Files: List of folder titles/categories; BM notes on 5x7 index cards listing partial contents of individual folders; List of audio cassettes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series II consists of a small number of books that accompany McNamara's subject files [7 folders].

did.unittitle: Brown, Wesley. Darktown Strutters: a novel. New York: Cane Hill Press, 1994.
[Program:] Gloucester Tercentenary Pageant. Presented at Stage Fort Park, Gloucester, MA. August 28th and 30th, 1923.
Elliott, Eugene Clinton. A History of Variety-Vaudeville in Seattle: From the Beginning to 1914. Seattle: University of Washington Press, 1944.
McEvoy, Harry K. Knife Throwing: a Practical Guide. Tokyo, Japan; Rutland, VT, USA: Charles E. Tuttle Co., 1977.
Brooks, Peter F. Pearly Kings and Queens in Britain. London: Barry Rose Publishers, n.d.

Mellor, G.J. Pom-Poms and Ruffles: The Story of Northern Seaside Entertainment. Yorkshire: Dalesman Publishing Company, Ltd., 1966. Clipping found inside the book, "Seasider's Diary: Confirming Blackpool's status," Evening Gazette, November 23, 1974.
MacKaye, Percy. The Roll Call: A Masque of the Red Cross. Washington, D.C.: National Headquarters American Red Cross, 1918. Copy from Glenn M. Loney.
Series III: Talks, Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series III: Drafts, manuscripts, and notes for published papers and articles, as well as printouts for talks and speaking engagements [76 folders].

Series IV: Anthologies [source materials].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series IV: Materials such as clippings, photocopied articles, notes, scripts, and correspondence relating to McNamara's Anthology of Popular Entertainments, as well as a British Play Anthology (1990) [21 folders.]

did.unittitle: Anthology - misc. outtakes, etc.: Photocopies, articles, scripts, drafts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series VI: Course materials and student work.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Although Series VI contains types of materials that are also located throughout Series I and filed thematically under specific subject headings, this box was originally separate and is organized more generally.
